fields.label_text:
MODEL STAIRCASE
mahogany and metal painted to imitate marble
GERMAN: 1800-50
Given by Her Majesty Queen Mary
W.55-1929

This model is a hand-crafted virtuoso piece, made to display the wood-turner's skill. It does not relate to any known staircase, although a wooden staircase of similar design can be seen at Chevening House, Kent. The Chevening staircase, on a circular and self-supporting scheme, was designed by the architect Nicholas Dubois in 1720 for James, first Earl Stanhope.

The model staircase originated in the collection of Queen Mary's sister in law, Margaret, Marchioness of Cambridge, who died in 1929.

fields.descriptive_line: English, 1800-40, mahogany, gift of Queen Mary
fields.physical_description: Model staircase made of mahogany on a painted metal base. The upper portion consists of two spiral flights of stairs meeting at the top in a landing with projecting semi-circular ends which is supported on a turned column ornamented with carved and faceted bosses. The stairs have hand-rails and turned balusters supported on a moulded stringing and finish in turned newel posts. This double-flight of stairs rests on a platform of oval shape surrounded by a hand-rail with balusters and on one side two further staircases descend, corresponding in design with the upper portioon. The metal plinth is painted in imitation of marble with light panels enclosed between darker borders.
fields.dimensions: Height: 2.3 ft, Width: 1.55 ft, Depth: 1.65 ft
fields.label:
MODEL STAIRCASE
mahogany and metal painted to imitate marble
GERMAN: 1800-50
Given by Her Majesty Queen Mary
W.55-1929

This model is a hand-crafted virtuoso piece, made to display the wood-turner's skill. It does not relate to any known staircase, although a wooden staircase of similar design can be seen at Chevening House, Kent. The Chevening staircase, on a circular and self-supporting scheme, was designed by the architect Nicholas Dubois in 1720 for James, first Earl Stanhope.

The model staircase originated in the collection of Queen Mary's sister in law, Margaret, Marchioness of Cambridge, who died in 1929. [1996]
fields.bibliography:
Sunday Times, October 1996. Interviews by Flynn Sarler
"We asked six V&A employees which exhibits they'd take home today, if they fancied instant dismissal. Here, then, are six of the very, very best. Interviews by Flynn Sarler. Photographs by David Harrison"
[...]
Roland Dawson
Mahogany model staircase (anon)

Roland Dawson has worked here for 16 years. He is a shift supervisor, in charge of the warders who look after the objects at the museum.

"I'm not a great do-it-yourself person. Once I tried to fix a shelf for my wife while my mind was elsewhere (with my beloved Arsenal - I was about to go to a match.) I just hammered these two ginormous nails into the wall. Every single person that came into the house after that was shown this shelf. "Come in", my wife would say. "Look what Curly's done." It was horrible. I have got a bit better, but when I look at my little shelves now and think "It's not bad", I remember this balcony and staircase. It drives me insane to know someone can be that brilliant. It's so perfect.

When I started here it was in the woodwork gallery. I looked after that part of the corridor and I used to stand next to it for hours, looking backwards and forwards to find a fault in it. Because it was hand-done and it was so intricate I thought there had to be something wrong somewhere. I even thought of it when I was in a different gallery: I'd think "I must have a look at that part next time, because I'm sure they couldn't have got it right." But they had.

It was put away about, oh, a dozen years ago, when the woodwork gallery became the shop. Then I became a fireman and didn't visit the stores so much. When I became a supervisor I opened the store doors one day and there she was. It must have been all of seven or eight years since I had last seen her. Still gorgeous. It's coming out again this month. It should be out - it's too beautiful to put away.

It annoys me sometimes that someone can be so clever as to make that, but if it was ever in danger, like from a fire or something, I'd be the first one passing it out the window, making sure it was safe."
fields.history_note:
This model is a hand-crafted virtuoso piece, made to display the wood-turner's skill. It does not relate to any known staircase, although a wooden staircase of similar design can be seen at Chevening House, Kent. The Chevening staircase, on a circular and self-supporting scheme, was designed by the architect Nicholas Dubois in 1720 for James, first Earl Stanhope.

The model staircase originated in the collection of Queen Mary's sister in law, Margaret, Marchioness of Cambridge, who died in 1929. After her death, Queen Mary donated it to the V&A.

In 1996, Roland Dawson, a shift supervisor at the V&A who had worked there since 1980, chose this staircase as his favourite exhibit for an article in the Sunday Times, October 1996. He was photographed with the staircase for the magazine.
